thread.section_title: NWAonline stories: High School Sports - Northwest Arkansas
thread.title: Episcopal dominant again

author: PETE PERKINS SPECIAL TO THE DEMOCRAT-GAZETTE
title: Episcopal dominant again
text:
By PETE PERKINS SPECIAL TO THE DEMOCRAT-GAZETTE Posted: October 21, 2015 at 2:34 a.m. 
The streaks continue for Little Rock Episcopal. 
Episcopal's boys team won its third consecutive Class 3A tennis state championship, its eighth in the past nine seasons, Tuesday at Burns Park Tennis Center in North Little Rock while its girls team won its eighth consecutive championship. 
Episcopal players also won the boys and girls singles and doubles finals to complete a sweep. 
Valley View sophomore Jonathan Hargrave said players from other teams understand what they are up against when they face off against Episcopal. 
"We know they're the team to beat," said Hargrave, who lost 6-0, 6-2 in the boys' singles final to Episcopal freshman Harrison Janes. "I mean, this is their home turf and they win every year, so whenever we think about the state tournament, it's always, 'Let's try to beat Episcopal.' 
"We look forward to it because of the competition they give, but at the same time we dread it, too." 
Episcopal Coach Andrea Barnett said Monday that her players' experience is central to their success. 
"We're very fortunate that most of them do play on their own and grew up playing," said Barnett, who coaches both the boys and the girls teams. "It's not difficult for me as a coach. We just have to figure out where to plug them in. We don't have to teach them how to play." 
Sophomore Shelby Worsham won her second consecutive girls singles title with a 6-2, 6-3 victory over Haas Hall sophomore Venesa Salinas. 
Janes took 20 minutes to complete his 6-0 first-set victory, an easy romp that inspired Hargrave to tailor a new attack. 
"In the second set I had a little more drive," Hargrave said. "I felt a little more desperate, so I started hitting my serves harder and I tried to play to his backhand, because his forehand is just so very good." 
Hargrave won the second serve of the second set to tie at 2-2. 
"I was very concerned," Janes said. "At 2-2, it could've gone either way. He's a really good player, but I really didn't see that coming. The second set was a lot harder for me than the first. He was playing a lot harder with more motivation to win." 
The fifth game was tied at 30 when Hargrave left the baseline in a dash to the net. He hoped to cut the angle on the shot he expected from Janes, a hard, relatively risk-free return. Instead, Janes hit a high lob. 
Hargrave quickly reversed course toward the baseline, but Janes' shot was too deep. It bounced 6 inches in, and Hargrave could manage no more than a shot that shanked out of bounds, 15 feet short of the net. 
"That lob came out of the blue," Hargrave said. "It was just a really good shot selection, and like all of his shots it was just very well executed." 
" I just thought at that moment I should hit a lob, and it was my best shot," Janes said. "It was at a good point in the match when it was really close." 
Hargrave said he thought Janes' forehand was unbeatable. 
"I've never played anyone with a forehand like that," he said. "It has to be one of the best in Arkansas." 
Sports on 10/21/2015
